question: Question_05_(b)
sols:
From our answer in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)}, we found that there were two critical points of the objective
function,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle \Lambda(x,y,z) = f(x,y,z) + \mu(x + y + z - 2) + \nu(x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2} - 2),\end{align*}
on \emph{C}. Those critical points corresponded to the critical points
of the function \emph{$f$(x,y,z) = z} restricted to the curve \emph{C}.
The values of \emph{z} corresponding to those critical points were
\emph{z = 0} and \emph{z = 4/3}. In contrast to
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)} where we looked for the larger of the two, we are now interested in
the smaller value \emph{z = 0}.

To find the corresponding \emph{x} and \emph{y} value, recall the
condition \emph{x = y} from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)}. Plugging this into the equation for the line, we obtain

\begin{align*}x + x + 0 = 2 \quad \rightarrow \quad x = y = 1\end{align*}

Therefore, the lowest point on \emph{C} is (1,1,0).
hints:
Consider that ``height'' in this case is referring the value of the
\emph{z} coordinate. In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)}, we were trying to find the maximum value of \emph{z} (i.e. the
maximum height) on \emph{C}. How can we use our answer from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/April_2012/Question_05_(a)}{part
(a)} to answer this question?
